title: Dirofilaria imitis
detail:
• Heartworm (important for dogs, possible in cats)
	• Microfilariae is the prelarval stage found in peripheral blood
• Located in the heart
• Transmission from mosquito bites
• Diagnosed by modified Knott, Millipore filtration, ELISA antigen test
• Clinical signs include lethargy, exercise intolerance, right sided cardiac enlargement; acute or chronic in cats; acute may result in death
• Treated with melarsomine (for adults) and a microfilaricide like ivermectin (for microfilariae), along with doxycycline and prednisone for side effects like lung congestion and pain/swelling at injection site, and cage rest for 1 month
• Controlled by preventives, reducing exposure to mosquitos

title: Toxoplasma gondii
detail:
• Located in the small intestines (cats)
• Infected by ingestion of cysts in meat or sporulated oocysts; transplacental or during nursing in kittens
• Diagnosed by fecal or centrifugal flotation
• Mostly asymptomatic in cats; kittens show signs of lethargy, depression, ascites, fever, death
• Treated with clindamycin
• Remove feces from environment, cook meat to control spread; pregnant women most at risk due to transplacental transmission

title: Toxacaris leonina
detail:
• Roundworm (cats and dogs)
• Located in the small intestines
• Infected by ingestion of infective egg or paratenic host
• Diagnosed by fecal or centrifugal flotation
• Clinical signs include weakness, dehydration, poor condition (in heavy worm burdens)
• Clean environment to control spread

title: Ancylostoma braziliense
detail:
• Hookworm (cats and dogs)
• Located in the small intestines
• Infected by ingestion of infective larvae, skin penetration
• Diagnosed by fecal or centrifugal flotation
• Clinical signs include emaciation, diarrhea, anemia, melena, weakness
• Treated with fenbendazole, moxidectin, pyrantel
• Clean environment to control spread
• Zoonotic potential—cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) through skin penetration

title: Dipylidium caninum
detail:
• Tapeworm (cats and dogs)
	• Proglottids: Segments contain eggs; break off from the body and expelled in feces
• Located in the small intestines
• Infected by ingestion of larvae in intermediate host (i.e., flea or lice)
• Diagnosed by proglottids identification, or fecal or centrifugal flotation
• Usually no clinical signs
• Treated with PO praziquantel (Droncit)
• Control intermediate hosts to control spread; treat all pets for tapeworm and fleas
• Taenia spp. and Echinococcus spp. also tapeworms of cats and dogs; infection from eating other animals and usually no signs

title: Cystoisospora spp.
detail:
• Coccidia (cats and dogs)
• Located in the small intestines
• Infected by ingestion of sporulated oocyst
• Diagnosed by fecal or centrifugal flotation
• Clinical signs include persistent diarrhea (may lead to emaciation and death)
• Clean environment to control spread

title: Parascaris equorum
detail:
• Equine roundworm
• Located in the small intestines
• Infected by ingestion of egg
• Diagnosed by fecal or centrifugal flotation
• No clinical signs in adults, may retard growth or cause colic in foals

title: Strongylus spp.
detail:
• Large strongyles (bloodworms) (horses)
• Located in the large intestines
• Infected by ingestion of larvae
• Diagnosed by fecal or centrifugal flotation
• Clinical signs include colic, fever, diarrhea, weight loss, death
• Strategic deworming to control spread

title: Giardia duodenalis
detail:
• Giardia (dogs, cats, cattle, horses, sheep, goats, pigs)
• Located in the small intestines
• Infected by ingestion of cyst
• Diagnosed by fecal or centrifugal flotation, ELISA antigen, or direct smear
• Clinical signs include diarrhea
• Treated with fenbendazole, praziquantel, pyrantel, febantel
• Zoonotic (fecal-oral route)

title: Acariasis
detail:
• Any infestation with acarines (mites or ticks)
• Mange is a general term for cutaneous acariasis

title: Arthropod
detail: • Parasites with jointed feet (insects, mites, ticks, as well as crustaceans and insects)

title: Cestode
detail:
• Tapeworm (adult stage)
	• TW parts: Scolex, neck, strobila (composed of proglottids)
• Usually found in the intestinal tract

title: Metacestode
detail: • Larvae of a tapeworm

title: Erythema
detail: • Redness of skin or mucus membranes

title: Hexacanth
detail: • A six-hooked larval stage of a tapeworm (cestode)

title: Nematode
detail:
• Roundworm
• Ascarids are a genus of nematodes

title: Oocyst
detail: • Egg-like offspring of coccidial parasites such as Cystoiosospora

title: Operculum
detail:
• A body part that acts as a lid to cover other more sensitive body parts
• Operculated eggs have a cap-like door at one pole (found in digenetic trematodes and pseudotapeworms)

title: Paratenic host
detail:
• Transport host; not necessary for the parasite’s life cycle
• Parasite doesn’t undergo further development but remains encysted (in suspended animation) until ingested by definitive host

title: Piriform
detail: • Pear-shaped

title: Common parasites
detail:
• Protozoa
	• One-celled, microscopic parasites like ameba and flagellates (e.g., giardia); diseases include malarias, coccidioses
• Helminths
	• Multi-celled, usually macroscopic parasites like flat-, round-, tapeworms, flukes; diseases include heartworm
• Ectoparasites and arthropods
	• Live on or in the skin, transmit infective organisms (flea, mosquito

title: Trematode
detail:
• Digenetic fluke; has two intermediate hosts in addition to the definitive host
• Class of flatworms

title: Volvulus
detail: • An obstruction caused by twisting of the stomach or intestine

title: Zygote
detail: • A single cell formed by the fusion of an egg and a sperm, containing the complete genetic material needed to develop into a new individual

title: Baermann technique [[image:Parasitology_Image01.png]]
detail:
• Used to recover nematode (roundworm) larvae from feces or soil
• Warm water stimulates larvae, which sinks to the bottom of a funnel
• After 24 hours, a drop of liquid is removed from the bottom of the funnel and placed on microscope slide

title: Sarcoptes scabei
detail:
• Scabies mite (most species)
• Spread by direct contact
• Diagnosed by skin scrapings
• Clinical signs include extreme pruritus and alopecia
• Treated with antiseborrheic shampoo and parasiticidal like Selamectin
• Controlled by cleaning environment (e.g. pyrethrins)
• Zoonotic

title: Otodectes cynotis
detail:
• Ear mite (cats, dogs, ferrets)
• Clinical signs include head shaking and tilt, scratching, dark odorous cerumen in outer ears
• Diagnosed from ear samples under the microscope
• Treated with pyrethrin compounds and rotenone
• Controlled by treating all pets living together

title: Demodex
detail:
• Skin mite, mange mite (cats and dogs)
• Transmitted only by intimate contact
• Clinical signs include alopecia, but nonpruritic unless there is secondary bacterial infection
• Diagnosed by deep skin scraping or plucked hair
• Rare but may be zoonotic
• Treated by parasiticidal shampoo followed by dipping (Amitraz (Mitaban)).

title: Ticks
detail:
• Dermacentor, ixodes, etc. are species
• Clinical signs include anemia and flaccid motor paralysis
• May also serve as intermediate hosts for protozoan parasites and as vectors for bacteria, viruses, etc.
• May be one-, two-, three-, or many-host ticks depending on how many hosts they feed on during different life cycles
• Zoonotic
• Fipronil and selamectin used as preventive in cats and dogs; pyrethrins, permethrins used in dogs (tick products for dogs should never be used in cats)

title: Ctenocephalides canis, felis, pulex
detail:
• Fleas
• Diagnosed visually
• Treated by monthly preventives to kill eggs, larvae, and adult fleas
• Controlled by cleaning environment
• Cat flea can cause cat scratch fever in humans by spreading Bartonella henselae in the feces
• Bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic plagues are caused by fleaborne Yersinia pestis

title: Trematodes
detail:
• Flukes
• Fasciola hepatica is found in sheep, cattle, horses, pigs, etc.; snail is intermediate host that is ingested
